training_phase.title: Training Phase
training_phase.explanation: This is where you teach the neural network your color preferences. Click 'I prefer this' on the color you like better. Each choice helps the network learn your taste!
training_phase.theory: Supervised learning with binary classification. The network learns a mapping from RGB color space to preference probability using gradient descent optimization.
training_phase.math: For each training example (x, y) where x is RGB values and y is preference (0 or 1): Loss = -[y*log(ŷ) + (1-y)*log(1-ŷ)] where ŷ is the network's prediction. Weights are updated using: w = w - α∇L where α is learning rate.

inference_phase.title: Prediction Mode
inference_phase.explanation: Now the neural network tries to predict which color you'll prefer! The bars show the network's confidence in each prediction.
inference_phase.theory: Forward propagation through trained network to compute preference probabilities. The softmax function converts raw outputs to probability distributions.
inference_phase.math: For input x, output ŷ = σ(W₂·ReLU(W₁·x + b₁) + b₂) where σ is sigmoid function: σ(z) = 1/(1+e⁻ᶻ). Confidence = max(ŷ, 1-ŷ) * 100%

color_displays.title: Color Options
color_displays.explanation: These are randomly generated colors. The network learns from your preferences between these pairs.
color_displays.theory: RGB color space representation with values in [0,255] range. Each color is a 3-dimensional vector representing red, green, and blue components.
color_displays.math: Color vector c = [r, g, b] where r,g,b ∈ [0,255]. Normalized input: x = [r/255, g/255, b/255] to scale values to [0,1] range.

prefer_buttons.title: Preference Buttons
prefer_buttons.explanation: Click these to tell the network which color you prefer. This creates training data for the neural network.
prefer_buttons.theory: Binary preference labeling creates supervised learning dataset. Each choice generates a training example with RGB input and binary preference output.
prefer_buttons.math: Training pair: (x, y) where x = [r/255, g/255, b/255] and y ∈ {0,1}. Dataset D = {(x₁,y₁), (x₂,y₂), ..., (xₙ,yₙ)}

training_stats.title: Training Statistics
training_stats.explanation: Training Examples: How many color choices you've made. Loss: How wrong the network's predictions are (lower is better). Accuracy: How often the network gets predictions right.
training_stats.theory: Real-time monitoring of training progress using binary cross-entropy loss and classification accuracy metrics.
training_stats.math: Loss = -(1/N)∑ᵢ[yᵢlog(ŷᵢ) + (1-yᵢ)log(1-ŷᵢ)]. Accuracy = (correct_predictions/total_predictions) × 100%. N = number of training examples.

start_inference.title: Start Prediction Mode
start_inference.explanation: Switch to prediction mode once you've trained the network with enough examples (at least 10).
start_inference.theory: Minimum training examples required for meaningful generalization. Prevents overfitting and ensures network has learned sufficient patterns.
start_inference.math: Minimum examples ≥ 10 for binary classification. Rule of thumb: at least 10 examples per class for basic learning.

prediction_bars.title: Prediction Confidence
prediction_bars.explanation: These bars show how confident the network is that you'll prefer each color. Higher percentage = more confident prediction.
prediction_bars.theory: Probability visualization of network's confidence in binary classification. Based on sigmoid output converted to percentage.
prediction_bars.math: Confidence = max(p, 1-p) × 100% where p = σ(z) is sigmoid output. Range: [50%, 100%] where 50% = uncertain, 100% = certain.

feedback_buttons.title: Feedback Buttons
feedback_buttons.explanation: Tell the network if its prediction was correct. If wrong, it will learn from the mistake and improve!
feedback_buttons.theory: Online learning with immediate feedback. Network updates weights based on prediction error using backpropagation.
feedback_buttons.math: Error = |prediction - actual|. Weight update: Δw = -α∇L where ∇L is gradient of loss with respect to weights.

weight_table.title: Neural Network Weights
weight_table.explanation: This shows the strength of connections between color inputs (RGB) and neurons. Positive values (green) strengthen connections, negative (red) weaken them.
weight_table.theory: Weight matrix visualization showing learned feature representations. Each weight represents connection strength between input and hidden layer neurons.
weight_table.math: Weight matrix W ∈ ℝ^(3×h) where h = hidden layer size. Element wᵢⱼ represents connection from input i to hidden neuron j.

weight_canvas.title: Weight Visualization
weight_canvas.explanation: Each square represents a weight in the neural network. Brighter squares = stronger positive weights, darker = stronger negative weights.
weight_canvas.theory: Heatmap visualization of weight matrix. Color intensity represents weight magnitude, hue represents sign (positive/negative).
weight_canvas.math: Normalized weight display: w_normalized = (w - min(w)) / (max(w) - min(w)). Color intensity ∝ |w|, hue ∝ sign(w).

training_insights.title: Training Insights
training_insights.explanation: Real-time analysis of how the network is learning your color preferences and what patterns it's discovering.
training_insights.theory: Interpretability analysis showing learned color preferences and decision boundaries. Reveals which color components (R,G,B) are most important.
training_insights.math: Feature importance = |∂ŷ/∂x| where x is input feature. Gradient magnitude indicates feature sensitivity.

color_sensitivity.title: Color Sensitivity Analysis
color_sensitivity.explanation: This shows which color component (Red, Green, or Blue) the network considers most important when making predictions. The dominant color has the strongest average weight connections.
color_sensitivity.theory: Feature importance analysis using weight magnitude as proxy for sensitivity. Higher average absolute weights indicate stronger influence of that color component on predictions.
color_sensitivity.math: Sensitivity = (1/n)∑ᵢ|wᵢ| where wᵢ are weights for color component. Dominant color = argmax(sensitivity_red, sensitivity_green, sensitivity_blue).

weight_changes.title: Weight Change Monitoring
weight_changes.explanation: This tracks how much the network's internal connections (weights) are changing during training. High activity means the network is actively learning, low activity suggests it's stabilizing.
weight_changes.theory: Learning dynamics analysis through weight change monitoring. Large changes indicate active learning, small changes suggest convergence or overfitting.
weight_changes.math: Average change = (1/n)∑ᵢ|Δwᵢ| where Δwᵢ = wᵢ_new - wᵢ_old. Activity level: High > 0.1, Medium > 0.05, Low ≤ 0.05.

learning_pattern.title: Learning Pattern Analysis
learning_pattern.explanation: This analyzes the recent trend in loss and accuracy to understand how the network is learning. Decreasing loss and increasing accuracy indicate good learning progress.
learning_pattern.theory: Learning curve analysis using recent training history. Monitors convergence patterns and identifies potential issues like overfitting or underfitting.
learning_pattern.math: Loss trend = sign(L₃ - L₁) where Lᵢ are last 3 loss values. Accuracy trend = sign(A₃ - A₁) where Aᵢ are last 3 accuracy values. Positive = improving, negative = degrading.

prediction_confidence.title: Prediction Confidence Assessment
prediction_confidence.explanation: This estimates how confident the network is in its predictions based on training performance. Higher confidence means the network has learned reliable patterns from your preferences.
prediction_confidence.theory: Confidence estimation based on training accuracy and data sufficiency. Combines model performance with training data quantity to assess prediction reliability.
prediction_confidence.math: Confidence = f(accuracy, training_examples) where f is confidence function. High: accuracy > 0.8, Medium: accuracy > 0.6, Low: accuracy ≤ 0.6 or insufficient data.

model_switcher.title: Model Switcher
model_switcher.explanation: Switch between two different learning approaches: Neural Network (learns complex patterns through gradient descent) and Rule-Based (HSV) (uses simple color space rules). Each model has different strengths and learning characteristics.
model_switcher.theory: Model comparison between parametric (neural network) and non-parametric (rule-based) approaches. Neural networks learn complex, non-linear decision boundaries, while rule-based models use interpretable color space heuristics.
model_switcher.math: Neural network: ŷ = f(x;θ) where θ are learned parameters. Rule-based: ŷ = Σᵢ wᵢ·ruleᵢ(x) where rules are predefined color heuristics.

color_preference_clicked.title: Training the Network
color_preference_clicked.explanation: You just taught the network! Your choice becomes training data. The network adjusts its weights to better predict your preferences next time.
color_preference_clicked.theory: Stochastic gradient descent with single example. Network updates weights immediately after each training example to minimize prediction error.
color_preference_clicked.math: For training example (x, y): w ← w - α∇L(w;x,y) where L is binary cross-entropy loss and α is learning rate (typically 0.01-0.1).

prediction_made.title: Network Prediction
prediction_made.explanation: The network analyzed both colors and predicted which one you'd prefer based on your previous choices. The confidence bars show how sure it is.
prediction_made.theory: Forward propagation through trained network to compute preference probabilities. Network applies learned decision boundary to new color pairs.
prediction_made.math: For colors c₁, c₂: p₁ = σ(f(c₁)), p₂ = σ(f(c₂)) where f is network function. Prediction = argmax(p₁, p₂), confidence = max(p₁, p₂).

feedback_given.title: Learning from Feedback
feedback_given.explanation: If the prediction was wrong, the network learns from its mistake and adjusts its weights. This is called 'supervised learning'!
feedback_given.theory: Error-driven learning where prediction errors guide weight updates. Network minimizes loss function through gradient descent.
feedback_given.math: Error = |ŷ - y|. Weight update: Δw = -α·∂L/∂w where L = -[y·log(ŷ) + (1-y)·log(1-ŷ)] and ∂L/∂w computed via backpropagation.

model_switched.title: Model Changed
model_switched.explanation: You switched to a different learning model! Neural Network: Uses gradient descent to learn complex patterns. Rule-Based (HSV): Uses simple color space rules. Notice how the training insights and visualizations change to reflect the different learning approach.
model_switched.theory: Model selection between different learning paradigms. Neural networks: high capacity, complex patterns, gradient-based optimization. Rule-based: interpretable, simple heuristics, statistical learning.
model_switched.math: Neural network complexity: O(h²) parameters where h = hidden layer size. Rule-based: O(k) rules where k = number of color bins. Different optimization strategies: gradient descent vs statistical counting.

training_complete.title: Training Update
training_complete.explanation: The network just finished learning from your choice. Notice how the weights, loss, and accuracy changed. The network is getting smarter!
training_complete.theory: Convergence monitoring showing training progress. Metrics track learning dynamics and model improvement over time.
training_complete.math: Loss decrease: ΔL = L(t) - L(t-1) < 0 indicates learning. Accuracy increase: ΔA = A(t) - A(t-1) > 0 indicates improvement.

inference_enabled.title: Ready for Predictions
inference_enabled.explanation: You've trained the network with enough examples! It's now ready to make predictions about your color preferences.
inference_enabled.theory: Model validation threshold reached. Network has sufficient training data to generalize to new color preferences.
inference_enabled.math: Training examples ≥ 10 satisfies minimum data requirement. Model ready when loss < threshold and accuracy > baseline.

neural_network.title: 🧠 Neural Network Model
neural_network.explanation: A neural network is like a digital brain that learns complex patterns from examples. It has layers of 'neurons' that process information and make predictions through gradient descent optimization.
neural_network.theory: Artificial neural networks are computational models inspired by biological neurons. They consist of interconnected nodes (neurons) organized in layers that process input data through weighted connections and activation functions.
neural_network.math: For input x, output ŷ = f(x;θ) where θ are learnable parameters. Each layer: h = σ(W·x + b) where σ is activation function, W is weight matrix, b is bias vector.

rule_based_model.title: 📊 Rule-Based (HSV) Model
rule_based_model.explanation: A rule-based model uses simple, interpretable rules based on HSV (Hue, Saturation, Value) color space. It learns your preferences by tracking which color bins you prefer most often.
rule_based_model.theory: Rule-based models use predefined heuristics and statistical patterns rather than learned parameters. They're more interpretable but may have limited capacity for complex patterns compared to neural networks.
rule_based_model.math: For color c, preference ŷ = Σᵢ wᵢ·binᵢ(c) where binᵢ(c) indicates if color c falls in bin i, and wᵢ is the learned preference weight for that bin.

training.title: How Training Works
training.explanation: Training means showing the network many examples and letting it adjust its internal connections (weights) to make better predictions.
training.theory: Training optimizes network parameters to minimize prediction error on training data. Uses gradient-based optimization algorithms to find optimal weight values.
training.math: Objective: min_θ L(θ) = (1/N)∑ᵢ L(f(xᵢ;θ), yᵢ) where L is loss function. Update rule: θ ← θ - α∇L(θ) where α is learning rate.

weights.title: Understanding Weights
weights.explanation: Weights are like the strength of connections between neurons. Positive weights strengthen connections, negative weights weaken them.
weights.theory: Weights determine the strength and direction of information flow between neurons. They encode learned patterns and relationships in the data.
weights.math: Weight wᵢⱼ connects neuron i to j. Output = σ(Σᵢ wᵢⱼ·xᵢ + bⱼ) where σ is activation function. Weight magnitude |w| determines connection strength.

loss.title: What is Loss?
loss.explanation: Loss measures how wrong the network's predictions are. Lower loss means better predictions. The network tries to minimize loss during training.
loss.theory: Loss function quantifies prediction error and provides optimization objective. Different loss functions are appropriate for different tasks (classification, regression).
loss.math: Binary cross-entropy loss: L = -[y·log(ŷ) + (1-y)·log(1-ŷ)] where y is true label, ŷ is predicted probability. Range: [0,∞) where 0 = perfect prediction.

accuracy.title: What is Accuracy?
accuracy.explanation: Accuracy shows what percentage of predictions the network gets right. Higher accuracy means the network is learning your preferences well.
accuracy.theory: Accuracy is a classification performance metric measuring the proportion of correct predictions. It's intuitive but may not capture all aspects of model performance.
accuracy.math: Accuracy = (TP + TN) / (TP + TN + FP + FN) where TP=true positives, TN=true negatives, FP=false positives, FN=false negatives. Range: [0,1].

overfitting.title: Overfitting
overfitting.explanation: When a network memorizes training data instead of learning general patterns. This demo uses techniques like dropout to prevent overfitting.
overfitting.theory: Overfitting occurs when model complexity exceeds data complexity, leading to poor generalization. Model performs well on training data but poorly on unseen data.
overfitting.math: Generalization gap = E[L_test] - E[L_train] where L is loss. Overfitting when gap is large. Regularization techniques reduce model complexity.

model_comparison.title: 🤖 Model Comparison
model_comparison.explanation: Neural Network: Learns complex, non-linear patterns through gradient descent. Better for complex preferences but less interpretable. Rule-Based (HSV): Uses simple color space rules. More interpretable but may miss complex patterns. Try both to see the difference!
model_comparison.theory: Different learning paradigms offer different trade-offs. Neural networks excel at complex pattern recognition but are 'black boxes.' Rule-based models are interpretable but may have limited expressiveness for complex relationships.
model_comparison.math: Neural Network: O(h²) parameters, complex decision boundaries. Rule-Based: O(k) rules, linear combinations of color bins. Complexity vs interpretability trade-off.
